author: lenoxjoseph

description.text:
I often find myself using up many cups each day because after I finish one drink, I dump it. When I am thirsty again, I fill up another cup and repeat the process. By then end of the day, I have used many cups all for 1 purpose: to quench my thirst.   
I decided to make a project to change that. This project is a "band" that wraps around the top of a kid's drink cup from a restaurant. You simply print the band and insert the cup into it. The band, attached to the cup, can then be attached to a 3M removable hook. Simply follow the instructions on the box for hanging the hook in the desirable location. Finally, fill up the cup with water (or another drink) and hang it on the hook. Whenever you want a drink, simply go over to it and have a sip. Once it's empty, you can refill it or wash the cup after removing the band. Problem solved!

I printed mine with supports, but you probably don't need to.   
Follow the on-box instructions for hanging the hook in the desired location. Then simply hang the cup, with the "band", on the hook.

author: Schorhr

description.text:
Here are a few parts that convert an Ikea Lillangen "foot base" assembly into a speaker stand.  These bases sell for between $10 and $20 each = MUCH cheaper than anything marketed as a speaker stand.  
The idea here is to raise the speaker off the ground and angle it upward so that the tweeters are aimed at the noggins of the listeners.  The dreidel shape of the tall feet is supposed to visually blend in with the square legs, while being rounded on the bottom to accommodate resting on the floor at an angle.  this shape also makes them easy to adjust by hand.  
If you wish to screw the bases directly to your speaker cabinets, (screws are included, they would be MUCH more secure that way, but I did not,) you'll need for each stand:  A pair of M8-1.25 bolts about 50% longer than the original feet, 4 M8-1.25 plain nuts (for use as lock nuts,) and a printed pair of the tall feet.  Use a vise to press the head of a long bolt into the hex recess in each foot until it bottoms out, thread a lock nut onto each foot, screw 'em into the legs, tighten the lock nuts at the desired height.  I printed my feet with 20% hex infill, 3 horizontal shells, 6 top/bottom shells.  
If you'd rather protect the bottoms of your cabinets, print the caps as well.  The rear caps have a slot into which you should insert a penny (or similar 1.5mm thick, 19mm diameter) coin.  The face of the coin touches the back of the cabinet and the stainless steel leg, forms a back-stop which prevents the cabinet from sliding rearward off of the stand.  (With the slot as a fulcrum, the penny becomes a lever with one end held stationary by the steel leg.)  I printed these solid.  Notice that the protrusion which inserts into the open top of the leg only sticks out 1.75mm... This is to clear a reinforcement plate welded inside each rear leg.  If you'd prefer to trim manually to clear this plate, you can increase the vertical scale to give a thicker pad, deeper penetration into the tube, (or re-design with a taller protrusion.)

For a PAIR of stands: (2) Ikea LIllangen foot bases close to the width/depth of your speakers.
(4) M8-1.25 hex head machine screws 40-50mm long.
(8) M8-1.25 plain hex nuts
(4) 1 cent coins (19mm diameter x 1.5mm thick) Print caps solid. Print feet with ~20% infill to save material. Make sure to use at least 1.5mm (6 layers if using 0.25mm layers) on the top/bottom to ensure wear life/strength. I used Taulman Nylon 618 filament on an un-heated Garolite bed with a space heater blowing on it. (~35degC build platform) I had to use an 8mm brim to aid adhesion. Note: If you'd prefer not to see the cross braces from the front, flip the base around, reverse the position of the tall feet, caps. After using these for a couple days, they aren't that sturdy without being screwed to something. If you want a battle-hardened stand you can drag around to position the speakers, this is not the one.

description.text: Chairman's Clock

Use this design to weigh food items while you cook. Simply fill the gradient measuring cup to the appropriate level until you cover up the number of ounces you're trying to weigh, and then balance the scale out!! So simple, yet very handy! This can make it more fun for anyone to measure out food weights. This design isn't limited to food either! Put this into a classroom setting and teach kids about equal balances, Center of Gravity, summation of forces, etc... ​
The device's operation is incredibly simple, and fairly accurate. Begin by supporting the beam assembly on the fulcrum of the base piece. You can slide the beam along the fulcrum in order to achieve a "zeroed" a.k.a. balanced state. Using this technique will allow you to put a tupperware or dish on the opposite side of the measuring cup while using this scale -- simply keep sliding the beam assembly along the fulcrum until you're balanced -- the beam will be flush to the top of the base piece once this is done. In the measuring cup, add water until you cover whatever number you wish -- this represents the amount of weight, in ounces, that will be needed on the other end of the balance. That's it! Very simple and effective!

Be SURE to print the measuring cup with a solid base, the remainder of the cup can be 30% or less -- or in the least, slosh some acetone in the bottom so the gaps close... if you don't do this, water will leak out.   
You can either print the square beam, or buy a wood one from a home improvement/ craft store.

description.text:
• Daily earrings prologue thingiverse.com/thing:7120
    • Space. The final fronteer! As SciFi fans, this was one thing we both looked forward to. (Yes, she's wearing this one, and it's allready one of her favorites!) The model is a rather simple combination of shapes (after trial and error), and might be done better with http://sketchuptips.blogspot.com/2008/08/preview-face-division.html (or simply use a forth of the "texture" if you have troubles with the tiny parts). I included all the work-in-progress pieces. UPDATE 1: I added some pictures of the 200% version (printed the file with the thinner lasers and removed the loop).
    I printed it on the ship's side, 30Â° support structure still had some drooping, so I colored the rough/noodly sagged parts as ship damage ;-)
    Still, it's awesome to have such a big version, even though the level of detail was designed for the small scale.
    When printing it this large, the pp3dp UP will create support under some of the texture parts, making it hard to clean- but again, coloring will fix most issues ;-)

Note 1: The second version has thinner lasers and bigger engines on the ship. Depending on the size and orientation, the thicker lasers may be neccesary.
Note 2: Print with the ship oriented correctly (as on the top image), this is fine if there is enough support. Cleaing can be an issue though (I had to glue one engine back on).  I tried printing it "standing" on the cube once (ship flying down), but the drooping resulted in missing engines.
Note 3: Some of the texture will come off and stick to the raft, due to the fact I only placed the texture-bits over the inverted texture. Colored it will look fine...
Coloring: Use glitter for the lazer, metallic for the cube, and a glossy or matte white/silver for the ship.

description.text: This is a 3D-Printed 3DS stylus made for the original 3DS and ther 3DS XL.  The stylus was made through Inventor 2013 and Inventor 2015 through precise measurements.  The prototype stylus used to make it was a DS Lite stylus.  I measured the stylus' circumference and the length.  Obviously, the stylus is bigger than it was supposed to be, but that doesn't mean it isn't good.  With a bigger stylus, using programs such as Flipnote 3D will be a lot easier to use.  And once you start using the stylus a lot you will get used to its size.  I only made this project for fun and to see how a 3D printed stylus would work and it turned out well.  If you're into The Legend of Zelda, you'll be happy to know that the stylus is LoZ themed!  Again, I hope you enjoy this stylus that I made for you guys and have fun playing your games with it.  Have a good day.

How I made the product is I took the DS Lite stylus and I reversed engineered it so it would be more suitable for 3DS users.  I then made precise measurements on the stylus and then recorded them on paper.  Then it was time for the designing,  I went to my computer and installed the program Inventor 2015 and got to work.  This is where I got help from a friend, so I can't take all the credit for this project.  My friend made a 2D shaped stylus and used the revolve tool to form the stylus.  We also had to make sure that the measurements were correct(which we thought they were right until I printed it out)so we edited the dimensions so they were correct.  Once we were done with that we added some text onto the stylus and some triforces and made a Fan-Made LoZ 3DS Stylus.  Once I me and my friend finished that, we saved it as an stl file and then waited until Monday to get it printed out.

My first project I wanted to build when I received my 3d printer was a R/C Tank, or something very similar, such as an FPV Tank. So I set off with my Raspberry pi, testing how to control two DC motors, and how to view where you are going. Using two ESC's, a PWM the Raspberry Pi, and some code, I am able to control the motors. I still need to connect a web cam connected via USB so I can see where I am going... but so far so good. I already have a working prototype. Don't mind the colors it'll be painted later :/ (was using up my beginner pack of multiple color filament) FOR THE CHALLENGE: This would be a great project for learning about 3d modeling and printing, electronics, coding, and sparking creativity. I have yet to finish mastering this myself, as it is a work in progress, but non-the-less it works, was a great build, fun to do, and my kids love driving it around. It has increased their interest into the fun world of fun DIY projects, and drive of learning by doing, and learning by failing.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

10%

I set forth with the idea of making a FPV tank powered with a Raspberry Pi for driving around the office, house, outside for fun. I then started doing some research on the google and found vexrobotics.com They sell kits for robots, and prototyping kits for DIY projects, but I did not want to be constricted with their pre-made DIY kits. However I did find some tank treads there, so I purchased them, as you cannot have a tank without some treads. I then busted out the old K'nex toys from my youth, and built a basic frame to gauge the distance and placement for the 2 motors, 2 tread drive/idler wheel, and the 4 double and 2 single bogie wheel assemblies. From there I took measurements of the Pi, proto breadboard, 2 battery packs, 2 servos, the motors, and the bogie wheel assemblies. After I had all the measurements down, I headed to Tinkercad.com and started modeling. I knew with my makerbot mini I was constricted to a build volume of 3.9 x 3.9 x 4.9 so I had to use some ingenuity to create a modular design that I could then fit together like a puzzle. After a few learning curves with the printer, it is somewhat complete. Update 12/23/2015 So after testing the prototype, I've learned that I definitely need to solve an issue.
Issue: Tank has a really hard time turning due to lack of torque/to much tred surface area touching ground.
Resolution 1 Primary: Add Gear Box from motor drive shaft to gear running treds. (didn't think about this and mounted tred drive gears directly on the drive shaft of the motor, thus, very minimal starting torque.)
Resolution 2 Temporary: Shorten the treds and frame or just treds, to limit the amount of tred surface area touching the ground.
By proping the tank up on its rear, like doing a wheelie or tredie? It was then able to turn, as the amount of treds touching the ground was reduced by about half.

comments.text:
UPDATE 5/25/2015
Seems I needed to do more homework before committing this entirely. As I've ran into two issues thus far, but have alleviated them.
The L239d chip does not put out enough amps for the motors I purchased, so I've upgraded to the L6205D, which also entails of not only the chip, but 6 capacitors, 3 resistors, and 2 diodes. I did a test run off of the one battery (7.2v 3000mAh NiMH battery) and one motor, and it fared well. However this new chip requires 8-52v in, and the battery is not that. So the motor ran for a good 30 second full power burst before the capacitors drained. I'll just purchase another of the same battery and put them in series to solve the power issue.

comments.text: Yes, PLA.  I am fairly new to 3d printing, and was going to build a version of RepRap, but after hearing about all the head ache from co-worker/friends, owners of RepRaps, I decided otherwise.  A majority wish they started with a manufactured 3d printer and then worked their way into a RepRap or something similar, as they all had some type of issues while making their printer.  So I took that info, did some research, and decided on the Makerbot Mini, which comes setup for PLA, so that is where I started.  I have not used ABS, however, after watching videos, and seeing how ABS has more flex and is less brittle, I think I may want to use it on some future projects.

Hello everyone !
This might be "just" software but i thought it might still be of interest to people on Thingiverse!
This is a system to control repraps/repraps remotely : It includes a Web client (using Javascript + Jquery + WebGl) and server (pure Python ) It includes manual control and gcode file printing, remote viewing of the print head movements (GCode based movement)in 3d (Webgl) , or optionally via webcam etc
It is still a very early , experimental version, but it is already usable (all my latest prints used it), and i have a ton of additional features planed and in progress.
Also, it is open source! You can find more info here :
https://github.com/kaosat-dev/Doboz/wiki/Doboz-web
and here:
http://objects.reprap.org/wiki/Doboz-Web
and you can grab the code here :
http://kaosat-dev.github.com/Doboz/
or here: https://github.com/kaosat-dev/Doboz I am looking for feedback , suggestions (feature addition aswell, webcam support was added on request) , or even collaborative work, so please don't hesitate to comment or contact me !

How to : install and configure
Update : 03/28/2011: for simplicity and clarity, and up to date instructions please visit https://github.com/kaosat-dev/Doboz-web/wiki/Doboz-web

author: wstein

description.text: This is a derivative of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:551366 Tried to make it a remix but kept getting errors on the upload page. This is for Digital Indicators that have a vertical screw mount in the rear (see gallery photos). I made it for use with my Digital Headspace gauge for reloading (Innovative Technologies). The jig is a fixture to mount in the bracket that comes on the Headspace gauge. Unless you have that specific instrument, you don't need it. If you do, print it out and glue in a 9mm bullet (I used a Berry's 115G LRN). The copper jacketed bullet allows for very free gliding across the build plate and also adds weight so it tracks well. Again, unles you have this specific instrument, you don't need it. You will have to make something for the end of the indicator you buy. The bracket is braced at each end so it should be very stiff and won't allow for flex due to the weight of the instrument and probe. Should fit Taz 4 and 5 (I have a Taz 5).

I printed it out in ABS with .15mm layers and 15% infill in the base and 30% infill in the indicator mounting tab (part that sticks up). To use, heat bed to normal printing temps (to account for swelling and warping at working temp). Move to the front left corner and zero.
Move to the front right and adjust hex screw until dial reads 0.
Return to front left and re-confirm zero.
Move to the back left and adjust hex screw until dial reads 0.
Return to front left and re-confirm zero.
Move to the back right and adjust hex screw until dial reads 0. Confirm all 4 corners and make any minor corrections. Finally check the center to confirm its near 0. It may or may not be zero depending on if your bed is sagging a little. At least you will know and by how much :)

comments.text: Leveling my bed is about get EASIER!  That, and I love the projectile used as your bed contact point...
comments.author: Sudsy

comments.text: Thanks Sudsy!  The 9mm bullet provides a smooth contact point and reduces friction when moving the carriage to the 4 corners.

title: XYZPrinting Da Vinci 1.0/2.0 Duo/AiO Left Belt Guard
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I made this left belt guard because I had a problem with my Da Vinci 2.0 Duo where the extruder cables would actually hit the left belt when the left nozzle was being wiped. The guard is held by three pins that you push into the left plastic rail holder. The pictures show the problem and how the guard is installed. I got a feeling this will only really happen on the Da Vinci 2.0 Duo since it had two extruders but the guard should fit on the 1.0 and 1.0 AiO if the need should arise. Enjoys :)

I made the pins have fairly tight tolerances so they would fit tightly into the rail holder holes. You may need to file the pins slightly to compensate for any kind of wobbling defects that might show up in the print. I also suggest to use a knife to remove the guard so none of the pins will break off accidentally.

title: Open Builds Acme Lead Screw conversion for Prusa X axis parts

description.text: Open Builds Acme Lead Screw and Nut Block conversion for Prusa X axis designed in Designspark Mechanical. I wanted to try out the M8 Lead Screw and Nut Block from http://openbuildspartstore.com/nut-block-for-8mm-metric-acme-lead-screw/ before I designed it into a new printer using the Open Builds V slot extrusion so I came up with these parts as a quick test of the Lead Screw and block. It is loosely based around the Aleph Objects Clamp X-ends, however I found some variations in the distance between the Z axis and Z linear rail so I made them the same as the original Prusa parts. I added a third mounting hole to clamp the X axis linear rails, Z stop adjustment screw mounting flange and used Open Builds M5 screws and T nuts. The T nuts will fit into the slight recess on the bottom side of the clamping plate and X ends where the Nut Block attaches. This is very much a work in progress, uploaded now to show someone else. I have printed a couple of versions of these parts but not installed them on a printer yet.

title: Bicycle Stand - 2 Part for use on the Road

description.text:
Many cyclists have bikes without a side stand so, when they stop, they have to find something to lean it up against or lay it on its side. This is a simple, compact and lightweight solution. The stand is in two parts that clips securely together in a matter of seconds. This makes it a practical, portable stand for use as/when required without the need to bolt it to the bike. Push it up under the frame adjacent to the tyre and lean the bike across against it as you lower the base of the stand onto the ground. The stand will be stable and secure provided the top arm has tension on the tyre as this stops it from rotating as well as applies some pressure against they tyre to create resistance that reduces the ability for the wheel to turn. This has been used on a number of mountain bikes, including bikes with different frame and wheel sizes. It has been designed to be as universal as possible as most bikes have similar dimensions in the key areas relevant to the use of this stand. Notes:
(1)The stand hasn't been used with road/racing bikes which have smaller tyres than mountain bikes. However, the principal is the same so it should work okay. The key is finding the spot where the stand is gripped by the side of the tyre as well as locked into the frame tube. (2) The stand is stable and will not easily fall once mounted correctly. However, it is not as stable as a permanently fixed stand (i.e. bolted on and made of metal) but as a quick and easy portable solution it does a brilliant job... a bike can be knocked over even with a bolted on stand. This is easier to knock over but unless it is knocked with a moderate force will continue to stand.

To support the weight of a bike this needs to be printed with greater than usual shells and infill. On a Replicator 2 the stand has worked well when printed with 4 shells and 30% (plus) infill.   
Use Raft but no support. The support required for the connector joint has been designed in and should break away cleanly and easily so the parts can be pushed together to create a snug fit that is firm can be pulled apart without great effort.   
The stand works well once you work out the best position for the bike concerned. It has been designed to be as universal as possible however different wheel widths, tyres and frame tube dimensions etc. will affect the final positioning for each bike as well as the angle at which it is supported.

title: Recipe Cards & Mobile Holder for Kitchen

description.text:
Here comes 3DShilp's "Recipe Cards & Mobile holder" for a modern kitchen, which can be mounted on the wall right above the countertop.  
You can stack all your recipe cards in the main box and place "recipe of the day" in the front tray for a clear view while cooking for reference.   
Also on the right side I have made a pocket / tray, where you can securely stack your mobile while you enjoy your cooking.  
I have also added funky stickers all over the body including mobile sticker for "iPhone", "OnePlus" & "Android" lovers. If demanded, I can add more STL files with alternatives mobile stickers. Currently, I have added blank version for other mobile users.  
Updated: Separated name tags from base to avoid overhang issues while printing. Now tags can be printed independently and glued to the base.

This is concept of Mechanical Kitchen Scale. It consist olny of 3D printed parts. It still need some improvements.. The idea of how it works is very simple: when main plate is going down under the weight the thread is rotating and tightening (winding up) the spring which has indicator attached to it. Video how prototype mechanism works: http://youtu.be/EllfBJKImgU

Pins i used are made from cutted 3mm filament.
Indicator should be glued to bottom of the spring.
Spring could be pre-winded up using printed hexagonal key.
Scissor mechanism need to be filed to run smoothly.

Two blocks with suction cups can easily hold 5-8 knifes, spoon, spatulas between them etc. All blocks can be connected to each other in every combination.  
There are hooks, knife holders, bread knife holder for knifes with bigger hilt, holder for mixers and universal ones for cutlery. The blank is also included.  
Let me know if some function is missing and I will add it.

The blocks are easy to print. To make the connector as tight as possible the blocks should be printed flat as they are. The block with the hook and the one for the suction cups needs support.  
Once you have a nice array of different tool holders you can glue the whole line together with a dap of hotglue.

remixed_from.author: AZ360VR
remixed_from.title: VR Headset for the OnePlus One Flagship Killer

description.text: I was inspired by the OnePlus VR goggles that someone on here made. The only problem is I have a nexus 5, so I decided to take the plunge and try to make my own VR goggles. I research on various designs, tons of google cardboard and professional gear like OSVR and Oculus. One set of Cardboard I saw was called DAVYCI Pro. It has some great features, it was small, collapsible and allows a user to mount any phone to it. I used their design as a base. Luckily for me I found some great lenses on amazon that works quite well and were cheap. I think the best design was the back plate, with 4 screws you can adjust any phone to the center of the viewing space. After playing with it, its kind of a pain to setup but I plan in the future to put channels for the bolts to slide in their direction plus use thumb screws. This is a work in progress. So far it works, but there are some flaws while using the rig. When I have time I will refine and improve the design. For anyone interested in the lenses, they're 38mm diameter and 50mm focal length. The only problem is even though they say they're 38mm when I ordered 3 (one as a spare), each one was larger. 39, 40 and gasp 41mm. So with the rig I used the 39 and 40 and just made the lens holder 40mm. So if you buy these lenses be forewarned. http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00EPQ9EVQ/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Hi ! I've just made a conversion to my replicator 2 to print some abs with a heatbed.
But my problem was in makerbot desktop, there is no possibility to heat up the heatbed since the genuine replicator 2 doesn't have it originaly.
So i've tweaked the Json profile, for it.
The only thing you need to do, is replace the files by these one, ( Makerbot/makerware/S3g/profiles ) and restart the conveyor service in makerware /makerbot desktop app
Compatible with 3.4/3.5 versions ( incoming mod for 3.6 ) Two files in the repository:
-one for people who installed the genuine rep2X heatbed
You can order it from makerbot.
-one for the Bottleworks one ( larger than the 2X ) /!\ If you own a replicator 2X too it will be recognised as a replicator2 ( single extruder and no heatbed) so keep your original files into a backup folder !
Feel free to like & share ;)))

remixed_from.author: MaximSachs
remixed_from.title: MaxGlide - Glidecam simple, efficient and cheap!

description.text:
Wanted to experiment with gimbals and camera stabilizers. Design wise I went a different route, I used squares instead of circles. Another thing I designed in was the ability to have one or two handles to control the rig. I used two different sets of ball bearings. Smaller ones for the gimbal to keep the design as small and light as possible, then normal skateboard ones for the center and handles. All in all, its balanced quite well. I tried different methods of counter weights and I ended up going with the glidecam's method since it works the best. In the end I had alot of problems getting the balance just right, I did the 3 second drop test and everything. I always had a little drift back and forth, so video looked as if I was on a boat. I think my issue is getting the top perfectly balanced, so I think I'll buy some bubble levelers and make a slide plate quick release setup. Thinking I can use some screws to allow small balance adjustments. Some of the things I used. 4mm x 13mm x 5mm Ball Bearings
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00AUB7M3C/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1 8x22x7 Ball Bearings
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00PI3ELZY/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 Double Lock Handle bars (The large bearings FIT PERFECTLY)
http://www.amazon.com/Locking-Bicycle-Handlebar-Mountain-Floding/dp/B00E35Y9P0/ref=sr_1_3?ie=UTF8&qid=1426083520&sr=8-3&keywords=handle+grip

• Four 4mm x 13mm x 5mm Ball Bearings
  • At least three 8x22x7 Ball Bearings
  • Two 5/16 Bolts, some nuts and one cupler.
  • Twelve 6-32 3/4 inch flat machine screws and nuts.
  • Four 6-32 1/2 inch flat machine screw and nuts
  • Four M4 25mm Socket Cap Screw
  • Twelve M4 nuts
  • One 1/4 1/2 inch bolt

title: Buildlog.net laser cutter ver2.0 xyz parts

description.text:
This is Barton Dring's buildlog.net laser cutter 2.0 (not the 2X laser cutter) x-y & z axis parts, plus the laser tube clamps for 3d printing. Printable pulleys to come later. The parts have been modified to fit on a true 100x100mm build platform. (no allowance for screw heads on stock BP's) Added M3 holes and nut slots for parts that would normally need to be tapped. I'd Also like to thank Nick Wilson for donating to the www.Pfierce.com Pflaser project; a low cost laser cutter project, because of you I thought I'd give back and help some others out by releasing this, thanks again! Buildlog.Net laser by Barton Dring is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 License.
Based on a work at www.buildlog.net.
Permissions beyond the scope of this license may be available at http://www.buildlog.net/cnc_laser/drawings.html.
This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 License.

title: Pi Illusion Cup
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Is this cup taller than it is around? How do you think the height of the cup compares to its circumference? If you ask your friends and don't let them measure, most of them will say that the cup is much taller than its circumference. However, this cup is actually SHORTER, and we can prove it with the help of the number pi. To see the proof and learn how this model was made using the new features in OpenSCAD 2015.03, go to Hacktastic:
http://mathgrrl.com/hacktastic/2015/03/pi-day-openscad-celebration/ =====

This design and all associated pictures and files are licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial Share Alike license. If you want to use designs, images, or files outside of the terms of this license, please email [email protected].

comments.text: Yes, great I made one. Didnt read your full description. Printed well. I thought the answer was going to be the same. Guess though!!! of course it looks to be taller than the circumference. Got calipers out, measured diameter, Pi d  - got circumference, measured height. Rechecked again and once more. Yep the circumference is slightly of higher length value than the height. Printed mine to be just 1 inch wide, came out at 1.094. I can live with that. Anyhow it is going to be my pen holder. Great job...mathgrrl

Go Pro Hero 3 fig rig. Handy for fast panning shots, or as a underwater camera holder. Uses 4x M8x50 cap head bolts and nylon nuts.
I used a heat gun to settle any tolerances when assembling. let me know if you like it. thanks! I want to see your MAKES! bottomslotselfstanding.STL included as a alternative bottom bar for those who want it to stand upright on a flat surface. for those wanting to make a new slot to hold a different item such as a phone... in the slot.
the depth is 6mm, the width is 40mm at the bottom 30mm at the top. angle is 50.45 deg. reduce all by a mm to have a fighting chance. Remember to wind in the nuts in and out of the nyloc nut first and use some lubricant on the the bolt.

comments.text:
Hey Jo. The software I used to design this was Solidworks 2014. Its industrial modeling software for real dimensionally critical applications. There is a tonne of videos online on how to do different things. to accomplish that drawing I had to follow this guide on knurling.. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Kpx8Csn1T24
My knurl was slightly different to accommodate for 3d printers so it comes out nice. It was trial and error.
Iv been playing with solidworks on and off since 2010 edition (actually 2012 IIRC). If you have any further questions on the software you can PM me.

description.text:
Snap together business card holder for a Laser Cutter
Forged at MakeWorks Coworking Studio in toronto. Check us out if you need access to prototyping tools, or need an awesomely fun place to make your startup happen.

Printer:

Trotec Speedy 300

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

• Cut all parts with protective coating
  • Remove protective coating from material.
  • Snap all parts in to one of the sides, starting at the bottom/front.
  • When one side is together, place object on it's side and begin pressing other sidepiece on from one side. As parts snap in, line up the next one so that it can drop down a bit more each time.
  • Fill with cards.
